maml:description.maml:para: Uploads a certificate to an Azure cloud service.
The Add-AzureCertificate cmdlet uploads a certificate for an Azure service.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the Azure service to which this cmdlet adds a certificate.
Specifies the certificate to deploy. You can specify the full path of a certificate file, such as a file that has a .cer or . pfx file name extension, or an X.509 Certificate object.
Specifies the certificate password.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the Azure service to which this cmdlet adds a certificate.
Specifies the certificate to deploy. You can specify the full path of a certificate file, such as a file that has a .cer or . pfx file name extension, or an X.509 Certificate object.
Specifies the certificate password.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Upload a certificate and password --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-AzureCertificate -ServiceName "ContosoService" -CertToDeploy ContosoCertificate.pfx -Password "password"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command uploads the certificate file ContosoCertificate.pfx to a cloud service. The command specifies the password for the certificate.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Upload a certificate file --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-AzureCertificate -serviceName "MyService" -CertToDeploy ContosoCertificate.cer

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command uploads the certificate file ContosoCertificate.cer to a cloud service. The command specifies the password for the certificate.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Upload a certificate object --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Certificate = Get-Item cert:\PATTIFULLER\MY\1D6E34B526723E06C235BE8E5457784BF12C9F39 PS C:\> Add-AzureCertificate -ServiceName "ContosoService" -CertToDeploy $Certificate

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets a certificate from the MY store of a user by using the Windows PowerShell core Get-Item cmdlet. The command stores the certificate in the $Certificate variable.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a data disk to a virtual machine.

The Add-AzureDataDisk cmdlet adds a new or existing data disk to an Azure virtual machine object. Use the CreateNew parameter to create a new data disk that has a specified size and label. Use the Import parameter to attach an existing disk from the image repository. Use the ImportFrom parameter to attach an existing disk from a blob in a storage account. You can specify the host-cache mode of the attached data disk.

maml:Description.maml:para: Indicates that this cmdlet creates a data disk.
Specifies the logical disk size, in gigabytes, for a new data disk.
Specifies the disk label for a new data disk.
Specifies the logical unit number (LUN) for the data drive in the virtual machine. Valid values are: 0 through 15. Each data disk must have a unique LUN.

Specifies the location of the blob in an Azure storage account where this cmdlet stores the data disk. If you do not specify a location, the cmdlet stores the data disk in the vhds container in the default storage account for the current subscription. If a vhds container does not exist, the cmdlet creates a vhds container.
Specifies the host level caching settings of the disk. Valid values are:
-- None
-- ReadOnly
-- ReadWrite
Specifies the virtual machine object to which this cmdlet attaches a data disk. To obtain a virtual machine object, use the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Indicates that this cmdlet imports an existing data disk from a blob in a storage account.
Specifies the disk label for a new data disk.
Specifies the logical unit number (LUN) for the data drive in the virtual machine. Valid values are: 0 through 15. Each data disk must have a unique LUN.

Specifies the location of the blob in an Azure storage account where this cmdlet stores the data disk. If you do not specify a location, the cmdlet stores the data disk in the vhds container in the default storage account for the current subscription. If a vhds container does not exist, the cmdlet creates a vhds container.
Specifies the host level caching settings of the disk. Valid values are:
-- None
-- ReadOnly
-- ReadWrite
Specifies the virtual machine object to which this cmdlet attaches a data disk. To obtain a virtual machine object, use the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Indicates that this cmdlet imports an existing data disk from the image repository.
Specifies the name of a data disk in the disk repository.
Specifies the logical unit number (LUN) for the data drive in the virtual machine. Valid values are: 0 through 15. Each data disk must have a unique LUN.
Specifies the host level caching settings of the disk. Valid values are:
-- None
-- ReadOnly
-- ReadWrite
Specifies the virtual machine object to which this cmdlet attaches a data disk. To obtain a virtual machine object, use the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Indicates that this cmdlet creates a data disk.
Specifies the logical disk size, in gigabytes, for a new data disk.
Specifies the disk label for a new data disk.
Specifies the logical unit number (LUN) for the data drive in the virtual machine. Valid values are: 0 through 15. Each data disk must have a unique LUN.

Specifies the location of the blob in an Azure storage account where this cmdlet stores the data disk. If you do not specify a location, the cmdlet stores the data disk in the vhds container in the default storage account for the current subscription. If a vhds container does not exist, the cmdlet creates a vhds container.
Specifies the host level caching settings of the disk. Valid values are:
-- None
-- ReadOnly
-- ReadWrite
Specifies the virtual machine object to which this cmdlet attaches a data disk. To obtain a virtual machine object, use the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Indicates that this cmdlet imports an existing data disk from the image repository.
Specifies the name of a data disk in the disk repository.
Indicates that this cmdlet imports an existing data disk from a blob in a storage account.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Import a data disk from the repository --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureVM "ContosoService" -Name "VirtualMachine07" | Add-AzureDataDisk -Import -DiskName "Disk68" -LUN 0 | Update-AzureVM

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets a virtual machine object for the virtual machine named VirtualMachine07 in the ContosoService cloud service by using the Get-AzureVM cmdlet. The command passes it to the current cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. That command attaches an existing data disk from the repository to the virtual machine. The data disk has a LUN of 0. The command updates the virtual machine to reflect your changes by using the Update-AzureVM cmdlet.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Add a new data disk --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureVM "ContosoService" -Name "VirtualMachine08" | Add-AzureDataDisk -CreateNew -DiskSizeInGB 128 -DiskLabel "main" -LUN 0 | Update-AzureVM

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets a virtual machine object for the virtual machine named VirtualMachine08. The command passes it to the current cmdlet. That command attaches a new data disk named MyNewDisk.vhd. The cmdlet creates the disk in the vhds container in the default storage account of the current subscription. The command updates the virtual machine to reflect your changes.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Add a data disk from a specified location --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureVM "ContosoService" -Name "Database" | Add-AzureDataDisk -ImportFrom -MediaLocation "https://contosostorage.blob.core.windows.net/container07/Disk14.vhd" -DiskLabel "main" -LUN 0 | Update-AzureVM

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets a virtual machine object for the virtual machine named Database. The command passes it to the current cmdlet. That command attaches an existing data disk named Disk14.vhd from the specified location. The command updates the virtual machine to reflect your changes.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a disk to the Azure disk repository.

The Add-AzureDisk cmdlet adds a disk to the Azure disk repository in the current subscription. This cmdlet can add a system disk or a data disk. To add a system disk, specify an operating system type by using the OS parameter.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the disk that this cmdlet adds.
Specifies the physical location of the disk in Azure Storage. This value refers to a blob page in the current subscription and storage account.
Specifies a disk label for the disk that this cmdlet adds.
Specifies the operating system type for a system disk. Valid values are:
-- Windows
-- Linux
If you do not specify this parameter, the cmdlet adds the disk as a data disk.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the disk that this cmdlet adds.
Specifies the physical location of the disk in Azure Storage. This value refers to a blob page in the current subscription and storage account.
Specifies a disk label for the disk that this cmdlet adds.
Specifies the operating system type for a system disk. Valid values are:
-- Windows
-- Linux
If you do not specify this parameter, the cmdlet adds the disk as a data disk.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Add a startup disk that uses the Windows operating system --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-AzureDisk -DiskName "MyWinDisk" -MediaLocation "http://contosostorage.blob.core.azure.com/vhds/winserver-system.vhd" -Label "StartupDisk" -OS "Windows"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a system disk to your disk repository. The system disk uses the Windows operating system.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Add a data disk --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-AzureDisk -DiskName "MyDataDisk" -MediaLocation "http://yourstorageaccount.blob.core.azure.com/vhds/winserver-data.vhd" -Label "DataDisk"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a data disk.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Add a Linux system disk --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-AzureDisk -DiskName "MyLinuxDisk" -MediaLocation "http://yourstorageaccount.blob.core.azure.com/vhds/linuxsys.vhd" -OS "Linux"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a Linux system disk.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a DNS server to an Azure service.
The Add-AzureDns cmdlet adds a DNS server to an Azure service.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies a friendly name for the DNS server. This name is not necessarily a fully qualified domain name.
Specifies the IP address of the DNS server.
Specifies the name of the service to which this cmdlet adds the DNS server.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies a friendly name for the DNS server. This name is not necessarily a fully qualified domain name.
Specifies the IP address of the DNS server.
Specifies the name of the service to which this cmdlet adds the DNS server.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Add a DNS server --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-AzureDns -ServiceName "ContosoService" -IPAddress 10.1.2.4 -Name "Dns07"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds the DNS server that has the address 10.1.2.4 to ContosoService.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds an endpoint to a virtual machine.
The Add-AzureEndpoint cmdlet adds an endpoint to an Azure virtual machine object.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies a name for the endpoint.
Specifies the protocol of the endpoint. Valid values are:
-- tcp
-- udp
Specifies the local, private, port that this endpoint uses. Applications within the virtual machine listen on this port for service input requests for this endpoint.
Specifies the public port that the endpoint uses. If you do not specify a value, Azure assigns an available port.
Specifies whether this cmdlet enables direct server return. Specify $True to enable, or $False to disable.
Specifies an access control list (ACL) configuration object for the endpoint.
Specifies the name of the internal load balancer.
Specifies the TCP idle time-out period, in minutes, for the endpoint.
Specifies the load balancer distribution algorithm. Valid values are:
-- sourceIP. A two tuple affinity: Source IP, Destination IP
-- sourceIPProtocol. A three tuple affinity: Source IP, Destination IP, Protocol
-- none. A five tuple affinity: Source IP, Source Port, Destination IP, Destination Port, Protocol
The default value is none.
Specifies the name of a virtual IP address that Azure associates to the endpoint. Your service can have multiple virtual IPs. To create virtual IPs, use the Add-AzureVirtualIP cmdlet.
Specifies the virtual machine to which the endpoint belongs.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the load balancer set for the endpoint.
Indicates that this cmdlet uses the no probe setting.
Specifies a name for the endpoint.
Specifies the protocol of the endpoint. Valid values are:
-- tcp
-- udp
Specifies the local, private, port that this endpoint uses. Applications within the virtual machine listen on this port for service input requests for this endpoint.
Specifies the public port that the endpoint uses. If you do not specify a value, Azure assigns an available port.
Specifies whether this cmdlet enables direct server return. Specify $True to enable, or $False to disable.
Specifies an access control list (ACL) configuration object for the endpoint.
Specifies the name of the internal load balancer.
Specifies the TCP idle time-out period, in minutes, for the endpoint.
Specifies the load balancer distribution algorithm. Valid values are:
-- sourceIP. A two tuple affinity: Source IP, Destination IP
-- sourceIPProtocol. A three tuple affinity: Source IP, Destination IP, Protocol
-- none. A five tuple affinity: Source IP, Source Port, Destination IP, Destination Port, Protocol
The default value is none.
Specifies the name of a virtual IP address that Azure associates to the endpoint. Your service can have multiple virtual IPs. To create virtual IPs, use the Add-AzureVirtualIP cmdlet.
Specifies the virtual machine to which the endpoint belongs.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the load balancer set for the endpoint.
Indicates that this cmdlet uses the default probe setting.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Add an endpoint --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Name "VirutalMachine01" | Add-AzureEndpoint -Name "HttpIn" -Protocol "tcp" -PublicPort 80 -LocalPort 8080 | Update-AzureVM

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves the configuration of a virtual machine named VirtualMachine01 by using the Get-AzureVM cmdlet. The command passes it to the current cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. This cmdlet adds an endpoint named HttpIn. The endpoint has a public port 80 and local port 8080. The command passes the virtual machine object to the Update-AzureVM cmdlet, which implements your changes.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Add an endpoint that belongs to a load balanced group --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureVM -ServiceName "LoadBalancedService" -Name "VirtualMachine12" | Add-AzureEndpoint -Name "HttpIn" -Protocol "tcp" -PublicPort 80 -LocalPort 8080 -LBSetName "WebFarm" -ProbePort 80 -ProbeProtocol "http" -ProbePath '/' | Update-AzureVM

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves the configuration of a virtual machine named VirtualMachine07. The current cmdlet adds an endpoint named HttpIn. The endpoint has a public port 80 and local port 8080. The endpoint belongs to the shared load balanced group named WebFarm. An HTTP probe on port 80 with a path of '/' monitors the availability of the endpoint. The command implements your changes.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Associate a virtual IP to an endpoint --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Name "VirtualMachine25" | Add-AzureEndpoint -Name "HttpIn" -Protocol "tcp" -LocalPort 8080 -PublicPort 80 -VirtualIPName "ContosoVip11" | Update-AzureVM

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves the configuration of a virtual machine named VirtualMachine25. The current cmdlet adds an endpoint named HttpIn. The endpoint has a public port 80 and local port 8080. This command associates a virtual IP to the endpoint. The command implements your changes.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds an internal load balancer to an Azure service.

The Add-AzureInternalLoadBalancer cmdlet adds an internal load balancer configuration to an Azure service. For a virtual network, you can specify a subnet or the IP address of the internal load balancer.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the internal load balancer that this cmdlet adds.
Specifies the name of the service to which this cmdlet adds an internal load balancer.
Specifies the name of the subnet for an internal load balancer that this cmdlet adds.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the internal load balancer that this cmdlet adds.
Specifies the name of the service to which this cmdlet adds an internal load balancer.
Specifies the name of the subnet for an internal load balancer that this cmdlet adds.
Specifies the virtual network IP address for an internal load balancer that this cmdlet adds.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the internal load balancer that this cmdlet adds.
Specifies the name of the service to which this cmdlet adds an internal load balancer.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the subnet for an internal load balancer that this cmdlet adds.
Specifies the virtual network IP address for an internal load balancer that this cmdlet adds.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Add an internal load balancer --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-AzureInternalLoadBalancer -ServiceName "ContosoWebsite01" -InternalLoadBalancerName "ContosoILB"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds an internal load balancer named ContosoILB to the service named ContosoWebsite01.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Add an internal load balancer for a specified subnet --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-AzureInternalLoadBalancer -ServiceName "ContosoWebsite01" -InternalLoadBalancerName "ContosoILB" -SubnetName "FrontEndSubnet"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds an internal load balancer named ContosoILB to the service named ContosoWebsite01. The command specifies the subnet named FrontEndSubnet.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Add an internal load balancer for a specified subnet and address --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-AzureInternalLoadBalancer -ServiceName "ContosoWebsite01" -InternalLoadBalancerName "ContosoILB" -SubnetName "FrontEndSubnet" -StaticVNetIPAddress 192.168.4.7

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds an internal load balancer named ContosoILB to the service named ContosoWebsite01. The command specifies the subnet named FrontEndSubnet and the static address of the virtual network.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds provisioning configuration for an Azure virtual machine.
The Add-AzureProvisioningConfig cmdlet adds provisioning configuration information to an Azure virtual machine configuration. You can use the configuration object to create a virtual machine.
This cmdlet supports different provisioning configurations, including standalone Windows servers, Windows servers joined to an Active Directory domain, and Linux-based servers.

To create an Active Directory domain joined server, specify the fully qualified domain name of the Active Directory domain and the domain credentials of a user who has permission to join the machine to the domain.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies a virtual machine object.
Indicates that this configuration disables the infrastructure as a service (IaaS) guest agent.
Specifies a data file for the virtual machine. This cmdlet encodes the contents of the file as Base64. The file must be less than 64 kilobytes long.
If the guest operating system is the Windows operating system, this configuration saves this data as a binary file named %SYSTEMDRIVE%\AzureData\CustomData.bin.

If the guest operating system is Linux, this configuration passes the data by using the ovf-env.xml file. Configuration copies that file to the /var/lib/waagent directory. The agent also stores the Base64 encoded data in /var/lib/waagent/CustomData.
Indicates that this configuration creates a standalone virtual machine that runs the Windows operating system.
Specifies the user name of the Administrator account that this configuration creates on the virtual machine.
Specifies the password of the administrator account.
Indicates that the virtual machine requires the user to change the password at the first logon.
Indicates that this configuration disables automatic updates.
Indicates that this configuration creates a virtual machine without a remote desktop endpoint.
Specifies the time zone for the virtual machine, for example, Pacific Standard Time or Canada Central Standard Time.
Specifies a set of certificates that this configuration installs on the virtual machine.
Indicates that this configuration enables WinRM over HTTP.
Indicates that this configuration disables Windows Remote Management (WinRM) on HTTPS. By default, WinRM is enabled over HTTPS.
Specifies a certificate that this configuration associates to a WinRM endpoint.
Specifies an array of X509 certificates that are deployed to a hosted service.
Indicates that this configuration does not upload the private key.
Indicates that this configuration does not add a WinRM endpoint for the virtual machine.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies a virtual machine object.
Indicates that this configuration disables the infrastructure as a service (IaaS) guest agent.
Specifies a data file for the virtual machine. This cmdlet encodes the contents of the file as Base64. The file must be less than 64 kilobytes long.
If the guest operating system is the Windows operating system, this configuration saves this data as a binary file named %SYSTEMDRIVE%\AzureData\CustomData.bin.

If the guest operating system is Linux, this configuration passes the data by using the ovf-env.xml file. Configuration copies that file to the /var/lib/waagent directory. The agent also stores the Base64 encoded data in /var/lib/waagent/CustomData.
Specifies the user name of the Administrator account that this configuration creates on the virtual machine.
Specifies the password of the administrator account.

Specifies an array of X509 certificates that are deployed to a hosted service.
Indicates that this configuration does not upload the private key.
Indicates that this configuration does not add a WinRM endpoint for the virtual machine.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Indicates that this configuration creates Windows server that is joined to an Active Directory domain.
Specifies the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of the domain to join.
Specifies the name of the domain of the account that has permission to add the computer to a domain.
Specifies the name of the user account that has permission to add the computer to a domain.
Specifies the password of the user account that has permission to add the computer to a domain.
Specifies the fully qualified name of the organizational unit (OU) in which the configuration creates the computer account.
Specifies a virtual machine object.
Indicates that this configuration disables the infrastructure as a service (IaaS) guest agent.
Specifies a data file for the virtual machine. This cmdlet encodes the contents of the file as Base64. The file must be less than 64 kilobytes long.
If the guest operating system is the Windows operating system, this configuration saves this data as a binary file named %SYSTEMDRIVE%\AzureData\CustomData.bin.

If the guest operating system is Linux, this configuration passes the data by using the ovf-env.xml file. Configuration copies that file to the /var/lib/waagent directory. The agent also stores the Base64 encoded data in /var/lib/waagent/CustomData.
Specifies the password of the administrator account.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Indicates that this configuration creates a Linux configuration.
Specifies the user name of the Linux administrative account that this configuration creates on the virtual machine.
Indicates that this configuration disables SSH.
Indicates that this configuration creates a virtual machine without an SSH endpoint.
Indicates that this configuration creates a virtual machine without an SSH password.
Specifies SSH public keys.
Specifies SSH key pairs.

Indicates that this configuration disables the infrastructure as a service (IaaS) guest agent.
Specifies a data file for the virtual machine. This cmdlet encodes the contents of the file as Base64. The file must be less than 64 kilobytes long.
If the guest operating system is the Windows operating system, this configuration saves this data as a binary file named %SYSTEMDRIVE%\AzureData\CustomData.bin.

If the guest operating system is Linux, this configuration passes the data by using the ovf-env.xml file. Configuration copies that file to the /var/lib/waagent directory. The agent also stores the Base64 encoded data in /var/lib/waagent/CustomData.
Indicates that this configuration creates a standalone virtual machine that runs the Windows operating system.
Specifies the user name of the Administrator account that this configuration creates on the virtual machine.
Specifies the password of the administrator account.
Indicates that the virtual machine requires the user to change the password at the first logon.
Indicates that this configuration disables automatic updates.
Indicates that this configuration creates a virtual machine without a remote desktop endpoint.
Specifies the time zone for the virtual machine, for example, Pacific Standard Time or Canada Central Standard Time.
Specifies a set of certificates that this configuration installs on the virtual machine.
Indicates that this configuration enables WinRM over HTTP.
Indicates that this configuration disables Windows Remote Management (WinRM) on HTTPS. By default, WinRM is enabled over HTTPS.
Specifies a certificate that this configuration associates to a WinRM endpoint.
Specifies an array of X509 certificates that are deployed to a hosted service.
Indicates that this configuration does not upload the private key.
Indicates that this configuration does not add a WinRM endpoint for the virtual machine.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Indicates that this configuration creates a Linux configuration.
Specifies the user name of the Linux administrative account that this configuration creates on the virtual machine.
Indicates that this configuration disables SSH.
Indicates that this configuration creates a virtual machine without an SSH endpoint.
Indicates that this configuration creates a virtual machine without an SSH password.
Specifies SSH public keys.
Specifies SSH key pairs.
Indicates that this configuration creates Windows server that is joined to an Active Directory domain.
Specifies the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of the domain to join.
Specifies the name of the domain of the account that has permission to add the computer to a domain.
Specifies the name of the user account that has permission to add the computer to a domain.
Specifies the password of the user account that has permission to add the computer to a domain.
Specifies the fully qualified name of the organizational unit (OU) in which the configuration creates the computer account.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Create a standalone virtual machine --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureVMConfig -Name "NonDomainVM" -InstanceSize Small -ImageName "Image07" | Add-AzureProvisioningConfig -Windows -Password "password" -AdminUsername "AdminMain" | New-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a virtual machine configuration object by using the New-AzureVMConfig cmdlet. The command passes that object to the current cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. The current cmdlet adds provisioning configuration for a virtual machine that runs the Windows operating system. The configuration includes the administrator user name and password. The command passes the configuration to the New-AzureVM cmdlet, which creates the virtual machine.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Create a domain joined virtual machine --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureVMConfig -Name "DomainVM" -InstanceSize Small -ImageName "Image09" | Add-AzureProvisioningConfig -WindowsDomain -Password "password" -AdminUsername "AdminMain" -ResetPasswordOnFirstLogon -JoinDomain "contoso.com" -Domain "contoso" -DomainUserName "DomainAdminUser" -DomainPassword "DomainPassword" -MachineObjectOU 'OU=AzureVMs,DC=contoso,DC=com' | New-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a virtual machine configuration object, and then passes it to the current cmdlet. The current cmdlet adds provisioning configuration for a virtual machine to be joined with the contoso domain. The command includes user name and password necessary to join the virtual machine to the domain. The configuration requires the user to change the user password at the first logon. The command creates the virtual machine based on the provisioning object.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Create a Linuxbased virtual machine --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureVMConfig -Name "LinuxVM" -InstanceSize Small -ImageName "LinuxImage03" | Add-AzureProvisioningConfig -Linux -LinuxUser "LinuxRoot" -Password "password" | New-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a virtual machine configuration object, and then passes it to the current cmdlet. The current cmdlet adds provisioning configuration for a virtual machine that runs the Linux operating system. The configuration includes the root user name and password. The command creates the virtual machine based on the provisioning object.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 4: Create a virtual machine that includes certificates for WinRM --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$certs = Get-ChildItem Cert:\CurrentUser\My New-AzureVMConfig -Name "NonDomainVM" -InstanceSize Small -ImageName "Image11" | Add-AzureProvisioningConfig -Windows -Password "password" -AdminUsername "AdminMain" -WinRMCertificate $certs[0] -X509Certificates $certs[1], $certs[2] | New-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService" -WaitForBoot

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets certificates from a certificate store, and then stores them in the $certs array variable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 5: Create a virtual machine that has WinRM enabled over HTTP --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureVMConfig -Name "NonDomainVM" -InstanceSize Small -ImageName "Image14" | Add-AzureProvisioningConfig -Windows -Password "password" -AdminUsername "AdminMain" -EnableWinRMHttp | New-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService" -WaitForBoot

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a virtual machine configuration object, and then passes it to the current cmdlet. The current cmdlet adds provisioning configuration that has WinRM enabled over HTTP. The command creates the virtual machine based on the provisioning object.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 6: Create a virtual machine that has WinRM disabled over HTTPS --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-AzureVMConfig -Name "NonDomainVM" -InstanceSize Small -ImageName "Image07" | Add-AzureProvisioningConfig -Windows -Password "password" -AdminUsername "AdminMain" -DisableWinRMHttps | New-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService" -WaitForBoot

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a virtual machine configuration object, and then passes it to the current cmdlet. The current cmdlet adds provisioning configuration that disables WinRM over HTTPS. The command creates the virtual machine based on the provisioning object.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 7: Create a virtual machine with no key export --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$certs = Get-ChildItem Cert:\CurrentUser\My New-AzureVMConfig -Name "NonDomainVM" -InstanceSize Small -ImageName "Image07" | Add-AzureProvisioningConfig -Windows -Password "password" -AdminUsername "AdminMain" -X509Certificates $certs[0], $certs[1] -NoExportPrivateKey | New-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService" -WaitForBoot

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets certificates from a certificate store, and then stores them in the $certs array variable.

maml:description.maml:para: Uploads a VHD file from an on-premise machine to a blob in a cloud storage account in Azure.

The Add-AzureVhd cmdlet uploads on premise Virtual hard disk (VHD) images to a blob storage account as fixed .vhd images. It has parameters to configure the upload process such as specifying the number of uploader threads that will be used or overwriting a blob which already exists in the specified destination URI. For on premise VHD images, patching scenario is also supported so that diff disk images can be uploaded without having to upload the already uploaded base images. Shared Access Signature (SAS) URI is also supported.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies a URI to a blob in Microsoft Azure Blob Storage. SAS in URI input is supported. However, in patching scenarios the destination cannot be a SAS URI.
Species the file path of the local .vhd file.
Specifies the number of threads to use for upload.
Specifies an URI to a base image blob in Azure Blob Storage. SAS in URI input is supported as well.
Specifies that this cmdlet deletes the existing blob in the specified destination URI if it exists.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies a URI to a blob in Microsoft Azure Blob Storage. SAS in URI input is supported. However, in patching scenarios the destination cannot be a SAS URI.
Species the file path of the local .vhd file.
Specifies the number of threads to use for upload.
Specifies an URI to a base image blob in Azure Blob Storage. SAS in URI input is supported as well.
Specifies that this cmdlet deletes the existing blob in the specified destination URI if it exists.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Add a VHD file --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-AzureVhd -Destination "http://contosoaccount.blob.core.windows.net/vhdstore/win7baseimage.vhd" -LocalFilePath "C:\vhd\Win7Image.vhd"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a .vhd file to a storage account.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Add a VHD file and overwrite the destination --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-AzureVhd -Destination "http://contosoaccount.blob.core.windows.net/vhdstore/win7baseimage.vhd" -LocalFilePath "C:\vhd\Win7Image.vhd" -Overwrite

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a .vhd file to a storage account.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Add a VHD file and specify the number of threads --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-AzureVhd -Destination "http://contosoaccount.blob.core.windows.net/vhdstore/win7baseimage.vhd" -LocalFilePath "C:\vhd\Win7Image.vhd" -NumberOfThreads 32

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a .vhd file to a storage account and specifies the number of threads to use to upload the file.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 4: Add a VHD file and specify the SAS URI --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-AzureVhd -Destination "http://contosoaccount.blob.core.windows.net/vhdstore/win7baseimage.vhd?st=2013-01-09T22%3A15%3A49Z&se=2013-01-09T23%3A10%3A49Z&sr=b&sp=w&sig=13T9Ow%2FRJAMmhfO%2FaP3HhKKJ6AY093SmveOSIV4%2FR7w%3D" -LocalFilePath "C:\vhd\win7baseimage.vhd"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a .vhd file to a storage account and specifies the SAS URI.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a virtual IP to a cloud service.
The Add-AzureVirtualIP cmdlet adds a new virtual IP (VIP) to your Azure service. The new virtual IP has a name but is not allocated an IP address.
The IP address is allocated only when you associate an endpoint to the VIP. See Add-AzureEndpoint for more details.
Your subscription is charged for extra VIPs only once they are associated with an endpoint.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the service.
Specifies the name of the virtual IP address.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the service.
Specifies the name of the virtual IP address.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Add a virtual IP to a service --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-AzureVirtualIP -VirtualIPName "Vip01" -ServiceName "ContosoService03" OperationDescription OperationId OperationStatus -------------------- ----------- --------------- Add-AzureVirtualIP 4bd7b638-d2e7-216f-ba38-5221233d70ce Succeeded

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a virtual IP address to a service.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a new operating system image or a new virtual machine image to the image repository.

The Add-AzureVMImage cmdlet adds a new operating system image or a new virtual machine image to the image repository. The image is a generalized operating system image, using either Sysprep for Windows or, for Linux, using the appropriate tool for the distribution.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the image being added to the image repository.
Specifies the location of the physical blob page where the image resides. This is a link to a blob page in the current subscription's storage.
Specifies the name of the icon that is used when the image is added to the repository.
Specifies the name of the small icon that is used when the image is added to the repository.
Specifies the operating system version of the image.
Specifies a label to give the image.
Specifies the End User License Agreement. It is recommended that you use an URL for this value.
Specifies the description of the operating system image.
Specifies a value that is used to group operating system images.
Specifies the date when the operating system image was added to the image repository.
Specifies the URL that points to a document that contains the privacy policy related to the OS image.
Specifies the size to use for the virtual machine that is created from the operating system image.
The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Medium
-- Large
-- ExtraLarge
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the image being added to the image repository.
Specifies the operating system disk configuration for the virtual machine image.
Specifies the name of the icon that is used when the image is added to the repository.
Specifies the name of the small icon that is used when the image is added to the repository.
Specifies the operating system version of the image.
Specifies a label to give the image.
Specifies the End User License Agreement. It is recommended that you use an URL for this value.
Specifies the description of the operating system image.
Specifies a value that is used to group operating system images.
Specifies the date when the operating system image was added to the image repository.
Specifies the URL that points to a document that contains the privacy policy related to the OS image.
Specifies the size to use for the virtual machine that is created from the operating system image.
The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Medium
-- Large
-- ExtraLarge
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the image being added to the image repository.
Specifies the location of the physical blob page where the image resides. This is a link to a blob page in the current subscription's storage.
Specifies the operating system version of the image.
Specifies a label to give the image.
Specifies the End User License Agreement. It is recommended that you use an URL for this value.
Specifies the description of the operating system image.
Specifies a value that is used to group operating system images.
Specifies the date when the operating system image was added to the image repository.
Specifies the URL that points to a document that contains the privacy policy related to the OS image.
Specifies the size to use for the virtual machine that is created from the operating system image.
The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Medium
-- Large
-- ExtraLarge
Specifies the name of the icon that is used when the image is added to the repository.
Specifies the name of the small icon that is used when the image is added to the repository.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the operating system disk configuration for the virtual machine image.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Add an operating system image to the repository --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$S = New-AzureVMImageDiskConfigSet PS C:\> Set-AzureVMImageOSDiskConfig -DiskConfig $S -HostCaching ReadWrite -OSState "Generalized" -OS "Windows" -MediaLink $Link PS C:\> Set-AzureVMImageDataDiskConfig -DiskConfig $S -DataDiskName "Test1" -HostCaching ReadWrite -Lun 0 -MediaLink $Link1 PS C:\> Set-AzureVMImageDataDiskConfig -DiskConfig $S -DataDiskName "Test4" -HostCaching ReadWrite -Lun 0 -MediaLink $Link PS C:\> Remove-AzureVMImageDataDiskConfig -DiskConfig $S -DataDiskName "Test4" PS C:\> $IMGName = "TestCREATEvmimage2"; PS C:\> Add-AzureVMImage -ImageName $IMGName -Label "Test1" -Description "Test1" -DiskConfig $S -Eula "http://www.contoso.com" -ImageFamily Windows -PublishedDate (Get-Date) -PrivacyUri '"http://www.test.com" -RecommendedVMSize Small -IconName "Icon01" -SmallIconName "SmallIcon01" -ShowInGui

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example adds an operating system image to the repository.

maml:description.maml:para: Exports an Azure virtual machine state to a file.
The Export-AzureVM cmdlet exports the state of a virtual machine to an .xml file.
Running Export-AzureVM, followed by Remove-AzureVM and then Import-AzureVM to recreate a virtual machine can cause the resultant virtual machine to have a different IP address than the original.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the Azure service that hosts the virtual machine.
Specifies the name of the virtual machine for which this cmdlet exports state.
Specifies the path and file name to which this cmdlet saves the virtual machine state.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the Azure service that hosts the virtual machine.
Specifies the name of the virtual machine for which this cmdlet exports state.
Specifies the path and file name to which this cmdlet saves the virtual machine state.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Export a virtual machine --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Export-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Name "ContosoRole06" -Path "C:\vms\VMstate.xml"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command exports the state of the specified virtual machine to the VMstate.xml file.

command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> {{ Add example code here }}

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the ACL configuration object from an Azure virtual machine.
The Get-AzureAclConfig cmdlet gets the access control list (ACL) configuration object from an existing Azure virtual machine.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the endpoint for which this cmdlet gets an ACL.
Specifies the virtual machine object for which this cmdlet gets ACL configuration.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the endpoint for which this cmdlet gets an ACL.
Specifies the virtual machine object for which this cmdlet gets ACL configuration.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Get an ACL configuration object for a virtual machine endpoint --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Acl = Get-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Name "VirtualMachine07" | Get-AzureAclConfig -EndpointName "Web"

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the virtual machine named VirtualMachine07 in the service named ContosoService by using the Get-AzureVM cmdlet. The command passes that object to the Get-AzureAclConfig cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. That cmdlet gets the ACL configuration for the endpoint named Web. The command stores that ACL configuration object in the $Acl variable.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets an Azure affinity group object.

The Get-AzureAffinityGroup cmdlet gets an Azure affinity group. The affinity group object includes the affinity group name, location, label, description and the storage and hosted services that are part of the affinity group.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the affinity group that this cmdlet gets. Names for affinity groups created through the Management Portal are typically GUIDs. The Management Port shows the affinity group label.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

Specifies the name of the affinity group that this cmdlet gets. Names for affinity groups created through the Management Portal are typically GUIDs. The Management Port shows the affinity group label.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Get properties of an affinity group --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureAffinityGroup -Name "South01"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the properties of the affinity group named South01.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets a certificate object from an Azure service.
The Get-AzureCertificate cmdlet gets a certificate object from an Azure service.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the Azure service from which this cmdlet gets a certificate.
Specifies the algorithm that is used to create the certificate thumbprint.
Specifies the thumbprint of the certificate that this cmdlet gets.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the Azure service from which this cmdlet gets a certificate.
Specifies the algorithm that is used to create the certificate thumbprint.
Specifies the thumbprint of the certificate that this cmdlet gets.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Get certificates from a service --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$AzureCert = Get-AzureCertificate -ServiceName "ContosoService"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets certificate objects from the service named ContosoService, and then stores them in the $AzureCert variable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Get a certificate from a service --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$AzureCert = Get-AzureCertificate -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Thumbprint '5383CE0343CB6563281CA97C1D4D712209CFFA97'

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the certificate object identified by the specified thumbprint from the service named ContosoService, and then stores it in the $AzureCert variable.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets Azure data disks.
The Get-AzureDataDisk cmdlet gets an object that represents the data disks on an Azure virtual machine. To get a specific data disk object, specify the logical unit number (LUN) of the disk.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the LUN for the data drive in the virtual machine. Valid values are: 0 through 15.
Specifies the virtual machine object for which this cmdlet gets data disks. To obtain a virtual machine object, use the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the LUN for the data drive in the virtual machine. Valid values are: 0 through 15.
Specifies the virtual machine object for which this cmdlet gets data disks. To obtain a virtual machine object, use the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Get all data disks for a virtual machine --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureVM "ContosoService" -Name "VirtualMachine07" | Get-AzureDataDisk

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the virtual machine named VirtualMachine07 in the service named ContosoService by using the Get-AzureVM cmdlet. The command passes the virtual machine to the current cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. The current cmdlet gets all the data disks for this virtual machine.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Get a specific data disk for a vitural machine --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureVM "ContosoService" -Name "VirtualMachine07" | Get-AzureDataDisk -LUN 2

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the virtual machine named VirtualMachine07 in the service named ContosoService. The command passes the virtual machine to the current cmdlet. The current cmdlet gets the data disk that has the LUN 2.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets details of a deployment.
The Get-AzureDeployment cmdlet gets details of an Azure deployment. Specify the name of the Azure service and the slot of the deployment.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the service.
Specifies the environment of the deployment. Valid values are: Staging or Production. The default value is Production.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the service.
Specifies the environment of the deployment. Valid values are: Staging or Production. The default value is Production.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Get details for a production deployment --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureDeployment -ServiceName "ContosoService"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command returns the details of the deployment for the service named ContosoService. This command does not specify a slot. Therefore, the command uses the default value of Production.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Get details for a staging deployment --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureDeployment -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Slot "Staging"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command returns the details of the staging deployment of ContosoService.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets information about events that Azure initiates that impact virtual machines and cloud services.

The Get-AzureDeploymentEvent cmdlet gets information regarding events that Azure initiates that impact virtual machines and cloud services. These events include planned maintenance events. This cmdlet returns a list of events that identify the role instance or virtual machine impacted, the reason for the impact, and the start time of the event.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the hosted service for which this cmdlet gets scheduled events.
Specifies the starting time for the scheduled events that this cmdlet gets.
Specifies the ending time for the scheduled events that this cmdlet gets.
Specifies the environment of the deployment for which this cmdlet gets scheduled events. Valid values are: Staging and Production. The default value is Production.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

Specifies the name of the deployment for which this cmdlet gets events.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets information about disks in the Azure disk repository.

The Get-AzureDisk cmdlet gets information about the disks that are stored in the Azure disk repository for the current subscription. This cmdlet returns a list of information for all disks in the repository. To view information for a specific disk, specify the name of the disk.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the disk in the disk repository about which this cmdlet gets information.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the disk in the disk repository about which this cmdlet gets information.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Get information about a disk --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureDisk -DiskName "ContosoDataDisk"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets information data about the disk named ContosoDataDisk from the disk repository.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Get information about all disks --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureDisk

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets information about all the disks in the disk repository.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Get information about a disk --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureDisk | Where-Object {$_.AttachedTo -eq $Null } | Format-Table -AutoSize -Property "DiskName","DiskSizeInGB","MediaLink"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets data for all of the disks in the disk repository that are not currently attached to a virtual machine. The command gets information about all of the disks, and passes each object to the Where-Object cmdlet. That cmdlet drops any disk that does not have a value of $Null for the AttachedTo property. The command formats the list as a table by using the Format-Table cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the DNS settings for an Azure deployment.
The Get-AzureDns cmdlet gets the DNS settings for an Azure deployment. The cmdlet returns the friendly name and IP address of the DNS server in a DNS settings object.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies a DnsSettings object.
Specifies a DnsSettings object.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Get DNS settings --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureDeployment -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Slot "Production" | Get-AzureDNS

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command uses the Get-AzureDeployment cmdlet to get the production deployment of the service named ContosoService. The command passes that object to the current cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. The current cmdlet gets the DNS settings.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets information about the endpoints that are assigned to an Azure virtual machine.
The Get-AzureEndpoint cmdlet gets information about the endpoints that are assigned to an Azure virtual machine.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the endpoint for which this cmdlet gets information.
Specifies the virtual machine from which this cmdlet gets endpoint information.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the endpoint for which this cmdlet gets information.
Specifies the virtual machine from which this cmdlet gets endpoint information.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Get endpoint information for a virtual machine --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Name "VirtualMachine12" | Get-AzureEndpoint

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves the configuration of a virtual machine named VirtualMachine12 by using the Get-AzureVM cmdlet. The command passes it to the current cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. This cmdlet gets endpoint information for that virtual machine.

The Get-AzureInternalLoadBalancer cmdlet gets the details of the internal load balancer configuration for an Azure service.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the available data center locations for the current Azure subscription.

The Get-AzureLocation cmdlet gets a list of the available Azure data centers and their properties for the current Azure subscription. Before you run this cmdlet, you must set your current subscription by using the Select-AzureSubscription and Set-AzureSubscription cmdlets.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Get locations --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureLocation

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets a list of available data centers, and their properties, for the current subscription.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the operating system disk of an Azure virtual machine.
The Get-AzureOSDisk cmdlet gets the operating system disk of an Azure virtual machine.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the virtual machine for which this cmdlet gets the operating system disk. To obtain a virtual machine object, use the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the virtual machine for which this cmdlet gets the operating system disk. To obtain a virtual machine object, use the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Get an operating system disk --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Name "VirtualMachine02" | Get-AzureOSDisk

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the virtual machine named VirtualMachine02 in the service named ContosoService by using the Get-AzureVM cmdlet. The command passes the virtual machine to the current cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. The current cmdlet gets the operating system disk of that virtual machine.

maml:description.maml:para: Lists all Azure guest operating systems.
The Get-AzureOSVersion cmdlet lists all the available Azure guest operating systems.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Get all available operating systems --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureOSVersion

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves an object that contains a list of all versions of guest operating systems that are available in the current subscription.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Display operating system information in a table --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureOSVersion | Format-Table -AutoSize -Property "Family", "FamilyLabel", "Version"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves an object that contains a list of all versions of guest operating systems that are available in the current subscription. The command passes them to the Format-Table cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. That cmdlet formats them as a table that shows the operating system family, operating system family label, and version.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the Public IP information for an Azure virtual machine.
The Get-AzurePublicIP cmdlet gets the Public IP information for an Azure virtual machine. To obtain the IP address of the Public IP, use the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the Public IP name.
Specifies the virtual machine for which this cmdlet gets Public IP configuration.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the Public IP name.
Specifies the virtual machine for which this cmdlet gets Public IP configuration.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Get Public IP configuration --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureVM -ServiceName "FTPInAzure" -Name "FTPInstance" | Get-AzurePublicIP

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the virtual machine named FTPInstance in the service named FTPInAzure by using the Get-AzureVM cmdlet. The command passes that virtual machine to the current cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. The current cmdlet gets Public IP configuration from the virtual machine.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets an RDP file for an Azure virtual machine.

The Get-AzureRemoteDesktopFile cmdlet downloads and saves a remote desktop connection (RDP) file for an Azure virtual machine. The cmdlet can launch a remote desktop connection to the specified virtual machine.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the Azure service to which the virtual machine belongs.
Specifies the virtual machine for which this cmdlet downloads an RDP file.
Specifies the full path of the downloaded RDP file on the local computer.
Indicates that this cmdlet starts a remote desktop session to the virtual machine.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the virtual machine for which this cmdlet downloads an RDP file.
Specifies the full path of the downloaded RDP file on the local computer.
Specifies the name of the Azure service to which the virtual machine belongs.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Indicates that this cmdlet starts a remote desktop session to the virtual machine.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Get an RDP file --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureRemoteDesktopFile -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Name "VirtualMachine07" -LocalPath "C:\temp\VirtualMachine07.rdp"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets an RDP file for the VirtualMachine07 virtual machine named VirtualMachine07 that runs on the service named ContosoService. The command stores that file as C:\temp\VirtualMachine07.rdp.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Start a remote session --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureRemoteDesktopFile -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Name "VirtualMachine07" -Launch

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets an RDP file for the VirtualMachine07 virtual machine named VirtualMachine07 that runs on the service named ContosoService. The command launches a remote desktop session. The command deletes the RDP file when the connection is closed.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets a reserved IP address by its name or lists all the reserved IP addresses in the subscription.
The Get-AzureReservedIP cmdlet gets a reserved IP address by its name or lists all of the reserved IP addresses in the subscription.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the reserved IP name.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the reserved IP name.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Get all reserved IP addresses --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureReservedIP

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all reserved IP addresses.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Get a reserved IP address with a specified name --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureReservedIP -ReservedIPName $IpName

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the reserved IP address that has the name specified by the $IpName variable.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns a list of roles in your Microsoft Azure service.

The Get-AzureRole cmdlet returns a list object with details on the roles in your Microsoft Azure service. If you specify the RoleName parameter, Get-AzureRole returns details on that role only. If you specify the InstanceDetails parameter, additional, instance-specific details are returned.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the Azure service.
Specifies the Azure deployment environment. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Production or Staging.
Specifies the name of the role to get.
Specifies that this cmdlet returns details about the instances on each role.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the Azure service.
Specifies the Azure deployment environment. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Production or Staging.
Specifies the name of the role to get.
Specifies that this cmdlet returns details about the instances on each role.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Get a list of roles for a service --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureRole -ServiceName "MySvc01" -Slot "Production"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command returns an object with details on all the production roles running on the MySvc01 service.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Get details on a role running on a service --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureRole -ServiceName "MySvc1" -Slot "Staging" -RoleName "MyTestVM3"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command returns an object with details on the MyTestVM3 role, running on the staging environment of the MySvc01 service.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Get instance information on instances of a role running on a service --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureRole -ServiceName "MySvc01" -Slot "Production" -RoleName "MyTestVM02" -InstanceDetails

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command returns an object with details on the instances of the MyTestVM02 role running in the production environment on the MySvc01 service.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 4: Get a table of the role instances associated with a service --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureRole -ServiceName "MySvc01" -Slot "Production" -InstanceDetails | Format-Table -Auto "InstanceName", "InstanceSize", "InstanceStatus"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command returns a table of the instance name, size, and status of all role instances running in the production environment on the MySvc01 service.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the role size information for the current subscription.
The Get-AzureRoleSize cmdlet gets the role size information for the current subscription.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the role size name, for example: ExtraSmall, Small, Large, ExtraLarge, A5, A6, A7.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the role size name, for example: ExtraSmall, Small, Large, ExtraLarge, A5, A6, A7.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Get role size information --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-AzureRoleSize
InstanceSize : A6 RoleSizeLabel : Cores : 4 MemoryInMb : 28672 SupportedByWebWorkerRoles : True SupportedByVirtualMachines : True OperationDescription : Get-AzureRoleSize OperationId : c5ed7b3a-03b3-548d-876b-6688c5b29cce OperationStatus : Succeeded
InstanceSize : A7 RoleSizeLabel : Cores : 8 MemoryInMb : 57344 SupportedByWebWorkerRoles : True SupportedByVirtualMachines : True OperationDescription : Get-AzureRoleSize OperationId : c5ed7b3a-03b3-548d-876b-6688c5b29cce OperationStatus : Succeeded

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets role size information for the current subscription.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Get role size information and specify the role size name --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-AzureRoleSize -InstanceSize A7
InstanceSize : A7 RoleSizeLabel : Cores : 8 MemoryInMb : 57344 SupportedByWebWorkerRoles : True SupportedByVirtualMachines : True OperationDescription : Get-AzureRoleSize OperationId : c5ed7b3a-03b3-548d-876b-6688c5b29cce OperationStatus : Succeeded

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets role size information for the specified role size.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Get role size information for all virtual machines in all of the Azure services --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureService | Get-AzureVM | Get-AzureRoleSize

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets role size information for all virtual machines in all of the Azure services.
