command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Create a Windows virtual machine configuration --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Image = (Get-AzureVMImage)[4].ImageName C:\PS> New-AzureVMConfig -Name "MyVM1" -InstanceSize ExtraSmall -ImageName $Image | Add-AzureProvisioningConfig -Windows -Password $AdminPassword | Add-AzureDataDisk -CreateNew -DiskSizeInGB 50 -DiskLabel "Datadisk1" -LUN 0 | New-AzureVM -ServiceName "MySvc1"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a Windows virtual machine configuration with operating system disk, data disk and provisioning configuration. This configuration is then used to create a new virtual machine.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Create a Linux virtual machine configuration --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Image = (Get-AzureVMImage)[7].ImageName C:\PS> New-AzureVMConfig -Name "MyVM1" -InstanceSize ExtraSmall -ImageName $Image | Add-AzureProvisioningConfig -Linux -LinuxUser $LinuxUser -Password $AdminPassword | Add-AzureDataDisk -CreateNew -DiskSizeInGB 50 -DiskLabel "Datadisk1" -LUN 0 | New-AzureVM -ServiceName "MySvc1"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a new Linux virtual machine configuration with operating system disk, data disk and provisioning configuration. This configuration is then used to create a new virtual machine.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a disk configuration set object.

The New-AzureVMImageDiskConfigSet cmdlet creates a disk configuration set object that is passed to the image update cmdlet. It encapsulates the OSDiskConfig and the DataDiskConfig object. Use the Set-AzureVMImageOSDiskConfig and Set-AzureVMImageDataDiskConfig cmdlets to set the OS Disk and Data Disk properties for the virtual machine image.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Create a disk configuration set object --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Disk = New-AzureDiskConfigSet PS C:\> $Disk = Set-AzureOSDiskConfig -DiskConfig $Disk -HostCaching ReadWrite PS C:\> $Disk = Set-AzureDataDiskConfig -DiskConfig $Disk -Name "Test" -HostCaching "ReadWrite" -LUN 0 PS C:\> Update-AzureVMImage -ImageName "Image2" -Label "Test1" -Description "Test1" -DiskConfigSet $Disk;

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a disk configuration set object and stores the results in the variable named $Disk. After the disk configuration is created, it is used to set the OSDiskConfig and DataDiskConfig. Then the virtual machine is updated with the configuration.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a configuration object for SQL Server automatic backup.
The New-AzureVMSqlServerAutoBackupConfig cmdlet creates a configuration object for SQL Server automatic backup.

maml:Description.maml:para: Indicates that automated backup for the SQL Server virtual machine is enabled. If you use this parameter, automated backup sets a backup schedule for all current and new databases. This updates your Managed Backup settings to follow this schedule.
Specifies a password to encrypt the certificate that is used to perform SQL Server encrypted backups.
Specifies a URI to the blob storage account.
Specifies the storage account to be used to store backups. Default is the storage account associated with the SQL Server virtual machine.
Specifies the storage key of the blob storage account.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Backup schedule type, manual or automated
Backup system databases
Sql Server Full Backup frequency, daily or weekly
Hour of the day (0-23) when the Sql Server Full Backup should start
Sql Server Full Backup window in hours
Sql Server Log Backup frequency, once every 1-60 minutes

Indicates that automated backup for the SQL Server virtual machine is enabled. If you use this parameter, automated backup sets a backup schedule for all current and new databases. This updates your Managed Backup settings to follow this schedule.
Specifies a password to encrypt the certificate that is used to perform SQL Server encrypted backups.
Specifies a URI to the blob storage account.
Specifies the storage key of the blob storage account.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the storage account to be used to store backups. Default is the storage account associated with the SQL Server virtual machine.
Backup schedule type, manual or automated
Backup system databases
Sql Server Full Backup frequency, daily or weekly
Hour of the day (0-23) when the Sql Server Full Backup should start
Sql Server Full Backup window in hours
Sql Server Log Backup frequency, once every 1-60 minutes

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Create an autobackup configuration using storage URI and account key --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$ABS = New-AzureVMSqlServerAutoBackupConfig -Enable -RetentionPeriod 10 -StorageUri $StorageUrl -StorageKey $StorageAccountKeySecure Enable : True EnableEncryption : False RetentionPeriodInDays : 10

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates an auto-backup configuration object by specifying storage URL and account key.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Create an autobackup configuration using storage context --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$ABS = New-AzureVMSqlServerAutoBackupConfig -StorageContext $StorageContext -Enable -RetentionPeriod 10 Enable : True EnableEncryption : False RetentionPeriodInDays : 10

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates an auto-backup configuration object by specifying storage context.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Create an autobackup configuration using storage context with encryption and password --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$ABS = New-AzureVMSqlServerAutoBackupConfig -StorageContext $StorageContext -Enable -RetentionPeriod 10 -EnableEncryption -CertificatePassword $CertPasswd Enable : True EnableEncryption : True RetentionPeriodInDays : 10

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates an auto-backup configuration object by specifying Storage context and enabling encryption option with password. The certificatepassword ist stored in the variable named $CertPasswd.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 4: Create an automatic backup configuration with manual backup schedule --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $storageUrl = 'https://stocrptestps9662.blob.core.windows.net/' $storageKey = ConvertTo-SecureString -String CDbJ5eqkPiR+mfmlHFRMVNtLyUMNn8asHs3ulyFeSUyibyg0JCofVh5/8hX4qE8GHoHtnQmIeAzwBTHC2hlvg== -AsPlainText -Force $backupConfig=New-AzureVMSqlServerAutoBackupConfig -Enable -ResourceGroupName crptestps9662 -BackupSystemDbs -BackupScheduleType Manual -FullBackupFrequency Daily -FullBackupStartHour 10 -FullBackupWindowInHours 10 -LogBackupFrequencyInMinutes 10 -RetentionPeriodInDays 10 -StorageUri $storageUrl -StorageKey $storageKey

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates and stores an automatic backup configuration object. The command specifies manual backup schedule with associated settings like FullBackupFrequency, FullBackupStartHour, FullBackupWindowInHours and LogBackupFrequencyInMinutes.

Enable : True EnableEncryption : False RetentionPeriod : 10 StorageUrl : https://stocrptestps9662.blob.core.windows.net/ StorageAccessKey : CDbJ5eqkPiR+mfmlHFRMVNtLyUMNn8asHs3ulyFeSUyi/byg0JCofVh5/8hX4qE8GHoHtnQmIeAzwBTHC2hlvg== Password : BackupSystemDbs : True BackupScheduleType : Manual FullBackupFrequency : Daily FullBackupStartTime : 10

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 5: Create an automatic backup configuration with automated backup schedule --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $storageUrl = 'https://stocrptestps9662.blob.core.windows.net/' $storageKey = ConvertTo-SecureString -String CDbJ5eqkPiR+mfmlHFRMVNtLyUMNn8asHs3ulyFeSUyibyg0JCofVh5/8hX4qE8GHoHtnQmIeAzwBTHC2hlvg== -AsPlainText -Force $backupConfig=New-AzureVMSqlServerAutoBackupConfig -Enable -ResourceGroupName crptestps9662 -BackupSystemDbs -BackupScheduleType Automated -RetentionPeriodInDays 10 -StorageUri $storageUrl -StorageKey $storageKey

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates and stores an automatic backup configuration object. The command specifies automated backup schedule.

Enable : True EnableEncryption : False RetentionPeriod : 10 StorageUrl : https://stocrptestps9662.blob.core.windows.net/ StorageAccessKey : CDbJ5eqkPiR+mfmlHFRMVNtLyUMNn8asHs3ulyFeSUyi/byg0JCofVh5/8hX4qE8GHoHtnQmIeAzwBTHC2hlvg== Password : BackupSystemDbs : True BackupScheduleType : Automated FullBackupFrequency : FullBackupStartTime :

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a configuration object for virtual machine automatic patching.
The New-AzureVMSqlServerAutoPatchingConfig cmdlet creates a configuration object for virtual machine automatic patching.

maml:Description.maml:para: Indicates that automated patching for the virtual machine is enabled. If you enable automated patching the cmdlet will put Windows Update into interactive mode. If you disable automated patching, Windows Update settings will not change.
Specifies the day of the week when updates should be installed.
The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Sunday
-- Monday
-- Tuesday
-- Wednesday
-- Thursday
-- Friday
-- Saturday
-- Everyday
Specifies the hour of the day when maintenance window starts. This time defines when updates start installing and is rounded to the hour.

Specifies the duration of the maintenance window. Automated patching will avoid performing an action that can impact a machine availability outside of that window. Only 30 minutes increments are allowed.
Specifies whether important updates should be included.

Indicates that automated patching for the virtual machine is enabled. If you enable automated patching the cmdlet will put Windows Update into interactive mode. If you disable automated patching, Windows Update settings will not change.
Specifies the day of the week when updates should be installed.
The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Sunday
-- Monday
-- Tuesday
-- Wednesday
-- Thursday
-- Friday
-- Saturday
-- Everyday
Specifies the hour of the day when maintenance window starts. This time defines when updates start installing and is rounded to the hour.

Specifies the duration of the maintenance window. Automated patching will avoid performing an action that can impact a machine availability outside of that window. Only 30 minutes increments are allowed.
Specifies whether important updates should be included.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet returns object contains settings for automated patching.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Create a configuration object to configure automatic patching --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$APS = New-AzureVMSqlServerAutoPatchingConfig -Enable -DayOfWeek "Thursday" -MaintenanceWindowStartingHour 11 -MaintenanceWindowDuration 120 -PatchCategory "Important" Enable : True DayOfWeek : Thursday MaintenanceWindowStartingHour : 11 MaintenanceWindowDuration : 120 PatchCategory : Important

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates configuration object that can be used to configure automatic patching using Set-AzureVMSqlServerExtension.

maml:description.maml:para: Publishes a desired state configuration script to Azure blob storage.

The Publish-AzureVMDscConfiguration cmdlet publishes a desired state configuration script to Azure blob storage, which later can be applied to Azure virtual machines using the Set-AzureVMDscExtension cmdlet.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the path of a file that contains one or more configurations. The file can be a Windows PowerShell script (.ps1 file), module (.psm1 file), or an archive (.zip file) that contains a set of Windows PowerShell modules, with each module in a separate directory.
Specifies the name of the Azure storage container the configuration is uploaded to.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.

Specifies the Azure storage context that provides the security settings used to upload the configuration script to the container specified by the ContainerName parameter. This context provides write access to the container.
Specifies the suffix for the storage end-point, for instance, core.contoso.net
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

Specifies the path of a file that contains one or more configurations. The file can be a Windows PowerShell script (.ps1 file), module (.psm1 file), or an archive (.zip file) that contains a set of Windows PowerShell modules, with each module in a separate directory.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies the path of a local .zip file that this cmdlet writes the configuration archive. The configuration script is not uploaded to Azure blob storage if you use this parameter.

Specifies the name of the Azure storage container the configuration is uploaded to.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.

Specifies the Azure storage context that provides the security settings used to upload the configuration script to the container specified by the ContainerName parameter. This context provides write access to the container.
Specifies the suffix for the storage end-point, for instance, core.contoso.net
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Publish a state configuration script to blob storage --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Publish-AzureVMDscConfiguration .\MyConfiguration.ps1

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a .zip package for the given script and any dependent resource modules and uploads it to Azure storage.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Publish a state configuration script to a local file --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Publish-AzureVMDscConfiguration .\MyConfiguration.ps1 -ConfigurationArchivePath .\MyConfiguration.ps1.zip

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a .zip package for the given script and any dependent resource modules and stores it in the local file .\MyConfiguration.ps1.zip.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes an ACL configuration object from an Azure virtual machine configuration.
The Remove-AzureAclConfig cmdlet removes an access control list (ACL) configuration object from an Azure virtual machine configuration.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the endpoint from which this cmdlet removes the ACL configuration.
Specifies the virtual machine from which this cmdlet removes an ACL configuration.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the endpoint from which this cmdlet removes the ACL configuration.
Specifies the virtual machine from which this cmdlet removes an ACL configuration.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Remove an ACL configuration --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Name "VirtualMachine07" | Remove-AzureAclConfig -EndpointName "Web" | Update-AzureVM

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the virtual machine named VirtualMachine07 in the service named ContosoService by using the Get-AzureVM cmdlet. The command passes that object to the current cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. That cmdlet removes the ACL configuration for the endpoint named Web. The command passes the result to the Update-AzureVM cmdlet, which updates the virtual machine.

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes an affinity group in a subscription.

The Remove-AzureAffinityGroup cmdlet deletes an Azure affinity group in the current subscription. You cannot delete an affinity group that has any members. You must first delete all the members of an affinity group.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the affinity group that this cmdlet deletes.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the affinity group that this cmdlet deletes.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Remove an affinity group --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureAffinityGroup -Name "South01"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command deletes the South01 affinity group in the current subscription.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes an availability set from an Azure virtual machine.
The Remove-AzureAvailabilitySet cmdlet removes an availability set from an Azure virtual machine.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the virtual machine from which this cmdlet removes an availability set.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the virtual machine from which this cmdlet removes an availability set.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a certificate from an Azure service.
The Remove-AzureCertificate cmdlet removes a certificate from an Azure service.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the Azure service from which this cmdlet removes a certificate.
Specifies the algorithm that is used to create the certificate thumbprint.
Specifies the thumbprint of the certificate that this cmdlet removes.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the Azure service from which this cmdlet removes a certificate.
Specifies the algorithm that is used to create the certificate thumbprint.
Specifies the thumbprint of the certificate that this cmdlet removes.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Remove a certificate from a service --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureCertificate -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Thumbprint '5383CE0343CB6563281CA97C1D4D712209CFFA97'

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the certificate object that has the specified thumbprint from the cloud service.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Remove all certificates from a service --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureCertificate -ServiceName "ContosoService" | Remove-AzureCertificate

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all the certificates from the service named ContosoService by using the Get-AzureCertificate cmdlet. The command passes each certificate to the current cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. That cmdlet removes each certificate from the cloud service.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Remove all certificates from a service that use a specific thumbprint algorithm --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureCertificate -ServiceName "ContosoService" -ThumbprintAlgorithm "sha1" | Remove-AzureCertificate

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all the certificates from the service named ContosoService that use the sha1 thumbprint algorithm. The command passes each certificate to the current cmdlet, which removes each certificate.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a data disk from an Azure virtual machine.
The Remove-AzureDataDisk cmdlet removes a data disk from an Azure virtual machine. By default, this cmdlet does not remove the data disk blob from the storage account.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the logical unit number (LUN) for the data drive in the virtual machine. Valid values are: 0 through 15.
Indicates that this cmdlet removes the data disk and the virtual hard disk (VHD) from blob storage.
Specifies the virtual machine object that is attached to the data disk. To obtain a virtual machine object, use the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the logical unit number (LUN) for the data drive in the virtual machine. Valid values are: 0 through 15.
Indicates that this cmdlet removes the data disk and the virtual hard disk (VHD) from blob storage.
Specifies the virtual machine object that is attached to the data disk. To obtain a virtual machine object, use the Get-AzureVM cmdlet.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Remove a data disk --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Name "VirtualMachine07" | Remove-AzureDataDisk -LUN 0

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the virtual machine named VirtualMachine07 in the service named ContosoService by using the Get-AzureVM cmdlet. The command passes the virtual machine to the current cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. The current cmdlet removes the data disk that has the LUN 0.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Remove a data disk and the virtual hard disk file --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Name "VirtualMachine07" | Remove-AzureDataDisk -LUN 0 -DeleteVHD | Update-AzureVM

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the virtual machine named VirtualMachine07 in the service named ContosoService. The command passes the virtual machine to the current cmdlet. The current cmdlet removes the data disk that has the LUN 0. The command includes the DeleteVHD parameter. Therefore, it also deletes the underlying virtual hard disk. The command updates the virtual machine to reflect your changes by using the Update-AzureVM cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes a deployment of a cloud service.
The Remove-AzureDeployment cmdlet deletes a deployment of an Azure cloud service. To delete a deployment, first suspend it.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the service for which this cmdlet deletes a deployment.
Specifies the deployment environment from which this cmdlet deletes the deployment. Valid values are: Staging and Production. The default value is Production.
Specifies that this cmdlet removes the deployment and the virtual hard disks (VHDs) from blob storage.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the service for which this cmdlet deletes a deployment.
Specifies the deployment environment from which this cmdlet deletes the deployment. Valid values are: Staging and Production. The default value is Production.
Specifies that this cmdlet removes the deployment and the virtual hard disks (VHDs) from blob storage.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Remove a deployment --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureDeployment -ServiceName "ContosoService"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the deployment of the Azure service named ContosoService. Because this command does not specify a slot, it removes the service from the production environment.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Remove a deployment and virtual hard disks --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureDeployment -ServiceName "ContosoService" -DeleteVHD

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the deployment of the service named ContosoService from the production environment. The command also removes the underlying virtual hard disks.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a disk from the Azure disk repository.

The Remove-AzureDisk cmdlet removes a disk from the Azure disk repository in the current subscription. By default, this cmdlet does not delete the virtual hard disk (VHD) file from blob storage. To delete the VHD, specify the DeleteVHD parameter.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the data disk in the disk repository that this cmdlet removes.
Indicates that this cmdlet removes the VHD from blob storage.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the data disk in the disk repository that this cmdlet removes.
Indicates that this cmdlet removes the VHD from blob storage.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Remove a disk --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureDisk -DiskName "ContosoDataDisk"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the disk named ContosoDataDisk disk from the disk repository. The command does not delete the VHD.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Remove and delete a disk --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureDisk -DiskName "ContosoDataDisk" -DeleteVHD

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the disk named ContosoDataDisk disk from the disk repository. This command specifies the DeleteVHD parameter. Therefore, the command deletes the VHD from Azure Storage.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a DNS server from an Azure service.
The Remove-AzureDns cmdlet removes a DNS server from an Azure service.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the DNS server that this cmdlet removes.
Specifies the name of the service from which this cmdlet removes a DNS server.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the DNS server that this cmdlet removes.
Specifies the name of the service from which this cmdlet removes a DNS server.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Remove a DNS server from a service --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureDns -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Name "Dns07"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the DNS server named Dns07 from ContosoService.

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes an endpoint from an Azure virtual machine.
The Remove-AzureEndpoint cmdlet deletes an endpoint from an Azure virtual machine object.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the endpoint that this cmdlet deletes from the virtual machine.
Specifies the virtual machine from which this cmdlet deletes an endpoint.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the endpoint that this cmdlet deletes from the virtual machine.
Specifies the virtual machine from which this cmdlet deletes an endpoint.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Remove an endpoint --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Name "VirutalMachine01" | Remove-AzureEndpoint -Name "HttpIn" | Update-AzureVM

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command retrieves the configuration of a virtual machine named VirtualMachine01 by using the Get-AzureVM cmdlet. The command passes it to the current cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. This cmdlet removes an endpoint named HttpIn. The command passes the virtual machine object to the Update-AzureVM cmdlet, which implements your changes.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes an internal load balancer configuration.

The Remove-AzureInternalLoadBalancer cmdlet removes the internal load balancer configuration from an Azure service. If any endpoint currently refers to the internal load balancer, this cmdlet cannot remove the configuration.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the service from which this cmdlet removes an internal load balancer.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the service from which this cmdlet removes an internal load balancer.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Remove an internal load balancer configuration --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureInternalLoadBalancer -ServiceName "ContosoService"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the internal load balancer configuration for the service named ContosoService.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes Public IP configuration from an Azure virtual machine.
The Remove-AzurePublicIP cmdlet removes Public IP configuration from an Azure virtual machine.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the Public IP name.
Specifies the virtual machine from which this cmdlet removes Public IP configuration.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the Public IP name.
Specifies the virtual machine from which this cmdlet removes Public IP configuration.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Remove Public IP configuration --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureVM -ServiceName "FTPInAzure" -Name "FTPInstance" | Remove-AzurePublicIP | Update-AzureVM

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the virtual machine named FTPInstance in the service named FTPInAzure by using the Get-AzureVM cmdlet. The command passes that virtual machine to the current cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. The current cmdlet removes Public IP configuration from the virtual machine. The command passes the virtual machine to the Update-AzureVM cmdlet, which implements your changes.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a reserved IP address by its name.
The Remove-AzureReservedIP cmdlet removes a reserved IP address by its name.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the reserved IP address.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the reserved IP address.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Remove a reserved IP address by its name --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureReservedIP -ReservedIPName $name

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes a reserved IP address by its name.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes the association from the reserved IP address to the VM or cloud service.

The Remove-AzureReservedIPAssociation cmdlet disassociates a reserved IP address from a virtual machine (VM) or Cloud Service. When the operation completes, the reserved IP address is free and the VM/VIP gets a dynamic public IP Address from the Azure Inventory.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the reserved IP address.
Specifies the name of the service.
Specifies a virtual IP address from which to remove the association with a service or VM.
Specifies the deployment environment. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Production, Staging.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Use this flag to bypass warning messages when removing the reserved IP association.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the reserved IP address.
Specifies the name of the service.
Specifies a virtual IP address from which to remove the association with a service or VM.
Specifies the deployment environment. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Production, Staging.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Use this flag to bypass warning messages when removing the reserved IP association.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Remove a reserved IP association --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureReservedIPAssociation -ReservedIPName "ResIp14" -ServiceName "PipTestWestEurope"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command disassociates the reserved IP address named ResIp14 from the service named PipTestWestEurope. PipTestWestEurope will be assigned a new dynamic VIP.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes the cloud service AD domain extension applied on all roles or named roles at a certain deployment slot.
The Remove-AzureServiceADDomainExtension cmdlet removes the cloud service Active Directory (AD) domain extension applied on all roles or named roles at a certain deployment slot.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of an Azure service.
Specifies the environment of the deployment to modify. Valid values are: Production or Staging.
Specifies an optional array of roles for which to specify the remote desktop configuration. If not specified, the AD domain configuration is applied as the default configuration for all roles.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of an Azure service.
Specifies the environment of the deployment to modify. Valid values are: Production or Staging.
Indicates that this cmdlet uninstalls all AD domain configurations from the cloud service.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of an Azure service.
Specifies the environment of the deployment to modify. Valid values are: Production or Staging.
Specifies an optional array of roles for which to specify the remote desktop configuration. If not specified, the AD domain configuration is applied as the default configuration for all roles.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Indicates that this cmdlet uninstalls all AD domain configurations from the cloud service.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Remove an AD domain extension --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureServiceADDomainExtension -ServiceName $Svc

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the extension specified by the $Svc variable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Remove an AD Domain extension for a specified role --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureServiceADDomainExtension -ServiceName $Svc -Role "WebRole1"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the service extension for the specified role.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes the antimalware configuration from a cloud service.

The Remove-AzureServiceAntimalwareExtension cmdlet removes the antimalware configuration and any associated antimalware monitoring from the Microsoft Antimalware extension associated with a cloud service.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the cloud service.
Specifies a deployment slot. Valid values are:
-- Production
-- Staging
The default value is Production.
Specifies an array of roles. The default value is all roles.
Specifies the storage endpoint suffix.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the cloud service.
Specifies a deployment slot. Valid values are:
-- Production
-- Staging
The default value is Production.
Specifies an array of roles. The default value is all roles.
Specifies the storage endpoint suffix.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

maml:alert.maml:para: This cmdlet removes only the configuration associated with the specified role. It does not uninstall or remove any already running instances of the Microsoft Antimalware extension from roles. To return these roles to a start state that does not have Microsoft Antimalware running, first remove the configuration by using this cmdlet, and then reimage or redeploy the service.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Remove the extension --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureServiceAntimalwareExtension -ServiceName "ContosoService03"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the antimalware extension and monitoring of associated antimalware events from the service named ContosoService03.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Remove the extension for the Staging slot --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureServiceAntimalwareExtension -ServiceName "ContosoService03" -Slot "Staging"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the antimalware extension and monitoring of associated antimalware events from all roles in the staging slot of the service named ContosoService03.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Remove the extension for a specified slot and role --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureServiceAntimalwareExtension -ServiceName "ContosoService03" -Slot "Production" -Role "web role"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the antimalware extension and monitoring of associated antimalware events from the service named ContosoService03 in the specified slot and role.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes the cloud service diagnostics extension applied on all roles or named roles at a certain deployment slot.
The Remove-AzureServiceDiagnosticsExtension cmdlet removes the cloud service diagnostics extension applied on all roles or named roles at a certain deployment slot.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the Azure service name of the deployment.
Specifies the environment of the deployment to modify. Valid values are Production or Staging.

Specifies an optional array of roles for which to specify the remote desktop configuration. If you do not specify this parameter, the remote desktop configuration is applied as the default configuration for all roles.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the Azure service name of the deployment.
Specifies the environment of the deployment to modify. Valid values are Production or Staging.
Indicates that this cmdlet uninstalls all RDP configurations from the cloud service.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the Azure service name of the deployment.
Specifies the environment of the deployment to modify. Valid values are Production or Staging.

Specifies an optional array of roles for which to specify the remote desktop configuration. If you do not specify this parameter, the remote desktop configuration is applied as the default configuration for all roles.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Indicates that this cmdlet uninstalls all RDP configurations from the cloud service.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Remove the diagnostic extension for a service --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureServiceDiagnosticsExtension -ServiceName $Svc

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the diagnostic extension for a specified role.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Remove the diagnostic extension for a service in a specified role --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureServiceDiagnosticsExtension -ServiceName $Svc -Role "WebRole01"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the diagnostic extension for a specified role.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes cloud service extensions that are applied on a deployment.
The Remove-AzureServiceExtension cmdlet removes cloud service extensions that are applied on a deployment.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the cloud service name.
Specifies the environment of the deployment to modify. Valid values are Production or Staging.
Specifies an optional array of roles to specify the extension for. If not specified the extension is applied as the default configuration for all roles.
Specifies the extension name.
Specifies the extension provider namespace.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the cloud service name.
Specifies the environment of the deployment to modify. Valid values are Production or Staging.
Specifies the extension name.
Specifies the extension provider namespace.
Indicates that this cmdlet uninstalls all configurations from the cloud service.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the cloud service name.
Specifies the environment of the deployment to modify. Valid values are Production or Staging.
Specifies an optional array of roles to specify the extension for. If not specified the extension is applied as the default configuration for all roles.
Specifies the extension name.
Specifies the extension provider namespace.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Indicates that this cmdlet uninstalls all configurations from the cloud service.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Remove a service extension --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureServiceExtension -ServiceName $Svc -Slot "Production" -ExtensionName "RDP" -ProviderNamespace "Microsoft.Windows.Azure.Extensions"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes a service extension.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Remove a service extension and uninstall all configurations --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureServiceExtension -ServiceName $Svc -Slot "Production" -ExtensionName "RDP" -ProviderNamespace "Microsoft.Windows.Azure.Extensions" -UninstallConfiguration

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes a service extension and uninstalls all configurations.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes the cloud service remote desktop extension applied on all roles or named roles at a specified deployment slot.

Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the Azure service name of the deployment.
Specifies the environment of the deployment to modify. Supported values are "Production" or "Staging".
Specifies that this cmdlet uninstalls all RDP configurations from the cloud service.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the Azure service name of the deployment.
Specifies the environment of the deployment to modify. Supported values are "Production" or "Staging".
Specifies an optional array of roles to specify the remote desktop configuration for. If not specified the remote desktop configuration is applied as the default configuration for all roles.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies that this cmdlet uninstalls all RDP configurations from the cloud service.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Remove the remote desktop extension --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureServiceRemoteDesktopExtension -ServiceName $svc

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the remote desktop extension.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Remove the remote desktop extension from a specified role --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureServiceRemoteDesktopExtension -ServiceName $svc -Role "WebRole1"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the remote desktop extension from a specified role.

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes a virtual IP address from your Cloud Service.

Specifies the name of the service from which to remove a virtual IP address.

The Remove-AzureVM cmdlet deletes an Azure virtual machine. This process does not delete the underlying .vhd files of the disks mounted on that virtual machine.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes an operating system image from the image repository.

The Remove-AzureVMImage cmdlet removes an operating system image from the image repository. By default, this cmdlet does not delete the associated physical image blob from the storage account. To delete the associated virtual hard drive (VHD), use the DeleteVHD parameter.

Specifies the operating system or virtual machine image to remove from the image repository.

Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Remove an image from the image repository --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureVMImage -ImageName "Image001"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the image named Image001 from the image repository.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Remove an image from the image repository and also the VHD --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-AzureVMImage -ImageName " Image001" -DeleteVHD

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the image named Image001 from the image repository and also deletes the physical VHD image from the storage account.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Set a subscription context and then remove all the images --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the subscription context and then removes all the images from the image repository whose Label includes the name Beta.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes the Microsoft Antimalware extension from a virtual machine.

The Remove-AzureVMMicrosoftAntimalwareExtension cmdlet removes the Microsoft Antimalware extension from a virtual machine. If monitoring was turned on, this cmdlet also removes the collection of Microsoft Antimalware events.

maml:alert.maml:para: To avoid interfering with monitoring for other applications or services, this cmdlet removes only the collection of Microsoft Antimalware events. It does not change other application configurations or the default monitoring configuration.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Remove a Antimalware extension --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService03" -Name "ContosoVM22" | Remove-AzureVMMicrosoftAntimalwareExtension | Update-AzureVM

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the Microsoft Antimalware extension. The command uses the Get-AzureVM cmdlet to get the specified virtual machine object, and then passes the object to the current cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. Remove-AzureVMMicrosoftAntimalwareExtension removes the extension. The command passes the result to the Update-AzureVM cmdlet to update the virtual machine.

maml:description.maml:para: Requests a reboot or reimage of a single role instance or all role instances of a specific role.

The Reset-AzureRoleInstance cmdlet requests a reboot or a reimage of a role instance that is running in a deployment. This operation executes synchronously. When you reboot a role instance, Azure takes the instance offline, restarts the underlying operating system for that instance, and brings the instance back online. Any data that is written to the local disk persists across reboots. Any data that is in-memory is lost.

Reimaging a role instance results in different behavior depending on the type of role. For a web or worker role, when the role is reimaged, Azure takes the role offline and writes a fresh installation of the Azure guest operating system to the virtual machine. The role is then brought back online. For a VM role, when the role is reimaged, Azure takes the role offline, reapplies the custom image that you provided for it, and brings the role back online.

Azure attempts to maintain data in any local storage resources when the role is reimaged; however, in case of a transient hardware failure, the local storage resource may be lost. If your application requires that data persist, writing to a durable data source, such as an Azure drive, is recommended. Any data that is written to a local directory other than that defined by the local storage resource will be lost when the role is reimaged.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the service.
Specifies the deployment environment where the role instances run. Valid values are: Production and Staging. You can include either the DeploymentName or Slot parameter, but not both.
Specifies the name of the role instance to reimage or reboot.
Specifies that this cmdlet reboots the specified role instance or, if none is specified, all role instances. You must include either a Reboot or Reimage parameter, but not both.
Specifies that this cmdlet reimages the specified role instance or, if none is specified, all role instances. You must include either a Reboot or Reimage parameter, but not both.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the service.
Specifies the deployment environment where the role instances run. Valid values are: Production and Staging. You can include either the DeploymentName or Slot parameter, but not both.
Specifies the name of the role instance to reimage or reboot.
Specifies that this cmdlet reboots the specified role instance or, if none is specified, all role instances. You must include either a Reboot or Reimage parameter, but not both.
Specifies that this cmdlet reimages the specified role instance or, if none is specified, all role instances. You must include either a Reboot or Reimage parameter, but not both.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Reboot a role instance --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>ReSet-AzureRoleInstance -ServiceName "MySvc01" -Slot "Staging" -InstanceName "MyWebRole_IN_0" -Reboot

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command reboots the role instance named MyWebRole_IN_0 in the staging deployment of the MySvc01 service.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Reimage a role instance --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>ReSet-AzureRoleInstance -ServiceName "MySvc01" -Slot "Staging" -Reimage

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command reimages the role instances in the staging deployment of the MySvc01 cloud service.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Reimage all role instances --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>ReSet-AzureRoleInstance -ServiceName "MySvc1" -Slot "Production" -Reimage

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command reimages all role instances in the production deployment of the MySvc01 service.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Restart a virtual machine --------------------------

maml:description.maml:para: Enables download of .vhd images.

The Save-AzureVhd cmdlet enables download of .vhd images from a blob where they are stored to a file. It has parameters to configure the download process by specifying the number of downloader threads that are used or overwriting the file which already exists in the specified file path.
Save-AzureVhd does not do any VHD format conversion and the blob is downloaded as it is.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) to the blob in azure_2.
Specifies the local file path.
Specifies the number of download threads that this cmdlet uses during download.
Specifies the storage key of the blob storage account. If it is not provided, Save-AzureVhd attempts to determine the storage key of the account in SourceUri from Azure.
Specifies that this cmdlet deletes the file specified by LocalFilePath file if it exists.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) to the blob in azure_2.
Specifies the local file path.
Specifies the number of download threads that this cmdlet uses during download.
Specifies the storage key of the blob storage account. If it is not provided, Save-AzureVhd attempts to determine the storage key of the account in SourceUri from Azure.
Specifies that this cmdlet deletes the file specified by LocalFilePath file if it exists.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Download a VHD file --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Save-AzureVhd -Source "http://contosoaccount.blob.core.windows.net/vhdstore/win7baseimage.vhd" -LocalFilePath "C:\vhd\Win7Image.vhd"

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Download a VHD file and overwrite the local file --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Save-AzureVhd -Source "http://contosoaccount.blob.core.windows.net/vhdstore/win7baseimage.vhd" -LocalFilePath "C:\vhd\Win7Image.vhd" -Overwrite

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command downloads a .vhd file and overwrites any file in the destination path.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Download a VHD file and specify the number of threads --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Save-AzureVhd -Source "http://contosoaccount.blob.core.windows.net/vhdstore/win7baseimage.vhd" -LocalFilePath "C:\vhd\Win7Image.vhd" -NumberOfThreads 32

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command downloads a .vhd file and specifies the number of threads.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 4: Download a VHD file and specify the storage key --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Save-AzureVhd -Source "http://contosoaccount.blob.core.windows.net/vhdstore/win7baseimage.vhd" -LocalFilePath "C:\vhd\Win7Image.vhd" -StorageKey "zNvcH0r5vAGmC5AbwEtpcyWCMyBd3eMDbdaa4ua6kwxq6vTZH3Y+sw=="

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command downloads a .vhd file and specifies the storage key.

maml:description.maml:para: Captures and saves the image of a stopped Azure virtual machine.

The Save-AzureVMImage cmdlet captures and saves the image of a stopped Azure virtual machine. For Windows virtual machines, run the Sysprep tool to prepare the image before it is captured. After the image is captured, the virtual machine is deleted.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the Azure service.
Specifies the name of the source virtual machine.
Specifies the name of the virtual machine image.
Specifies the label of the virtual machine image.
Specifies the operation system state for the virtual machine image. Use this parameter if you intend to capture a virtual machine image to Azure.
Valid values are:
-- Generalized
-- Specialized
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the Azure service.
Specifies the name of the source virtual machine.
Specifies the name of the virtual machine image.
Specifies the label of the virtual machine image.
Specifies the operation system state for the virtual machine image. Use this parameter if you intend to capture a virtual machine image to Azure.
Valid values are:
-- Generalized
-- Specialized
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Save an existing virtual machine and then delete it from a deployment --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Save-AzureVMImage -ServiceName "MyService" -Name "MyVM" -NewImageName "MyBaseImage" -NewImageLabel "MyBaseVM"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command captures an existing virtual machine and deletes it from the deployment.

maml:description.maml:para: Modifies an ACL configuration object.
The Set-AzureAclConfig cmdlet modifies an access control list (ACL) configuration object from an existing Azure virtual machine configuration.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the action for the rule that this cmdlet adds or modifies. Valid values are: Permit and Deny.
Specifies the remote subnet for the rule that this cmdlet adds or modifies. Specifies an address in Classless Interdomain Routing (CIDR) format.
Specifies the processing order for the rule that this cmdlet adds or modifies.
Specifies a description for the rule that this cmdlet adds or modifies.
Indicates that this cmdlet adds a rule to the ACL configuration.
Specifies an ACL configuration object that this cmdlet modifies.
Specifies the action for the rule that this cmdlet adds or modifies. Valid values are: Permit and Deny.
Specifies the ID of the rule that this cmdlet removes or modifies for the ACL configuration.
Specifies the remote subnet for the rule that this cmdlet adds or modifies. Specifies an address in Classless Interdomain Routing (CIDR) format.
Specifies the processing order for the rule that this cmdlet adds or modifies.
Specifies a description for the rule that this cmdlet adds or modifies.
Specifies an ACL configuration object that this cmdlet modifies.
Indicates that this cmdlet modifies a rule in the ACL configuration.
Specifies the ID of the rule that this cmdlet removes or modifies for the ACL configuration.
Specifies an ACL configuration object that this cmdlet modifies.
Indicates that this cmdlet removes a rule from the ACL configuration.
Indicates that this cmdlet adds a rule to the ACL configuration.
Specifies the action for the rule that this cmdlet adds or modifies. Valid values are: Permit and Deny.
Specifies the remote subnet for the rule that this cmdlet adds or modifies. Specifies an address in Classless Interdomain Routing (CIDR) format.
Specifies the processing order for the rule that this cmdlet adds or modifies.
Specifies a description for the rule that this cmdlet adds or modifies.
Specifies an ACL configuration object that this cmdlet modifies.
Indicates that this cmdlet removes a rule from the ACL configuration.
Specifies the ID of the rule that this cmdlet removes or modifies for the ACL configuration.
Indicates that this cmdlet modifies a rule in the ACL configuration.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Add a rule to a new ACL configuration --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Acl = New-AzureAclConfig PS C:\> Set-AzureAclConfig -AddRule -ACL $Acl -Action Permit -RemoteSubnet "172.0.0.0/8" -Order 100 -Description "Permit ACL rule"

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command creates an ACL configuration, and then stores it in the $Acl variable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2: Modify a rule in an ACL configuration --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Acl = Get-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Name "VirtualMachine07" | Get-AzureAclConfig -EndpointName "Web" PS C:\> Set-AzureAclConfig -SetRule -RuleId 0 -ACL $Acl -Order 102 -Description "Web endpoint rule" PS C:\> Get-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Name "VirtualMachine07" | Set-AzureEndpoint -ACL $Acl -Name "Web" | Update-AzureVM

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command gets the virtual machine named VirtualMachine07 in the service named ContosoService by using the Get-AzureVM cmdlet. The command passes that object to the Get-AzureAclConfig cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. That cmdlet gets the ACL configuration for the endpoint named Web. The command stores that ACL configuration object in the $Acl variable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3: Remove a rule from an ACL configuration --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>$Acl = Get-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Name "VirtualMachine07" | Get-AzureAclConfig -EndpointName "Web" PS C:\> Set-AzureAclConfig -RemoveRule -ID 0 -ACL $Acl PS C:\> Get-AzureVM -ServiceName "ContosoService" -Name "VirtualMachine07" | Set-AzureEndpoint -ACL $Acl -Name "Web" | Update-AzureVM

dev:remarks.maml:para: The first command stores an ACL configuration object in the $Acl variable. This is the same as the previous example.

maml:description.maml:para: Modifies properties of an affinity group.
The Set-AzureAffinityGroup cmdlet modifies properties of an Azure affinity group. You can change the label and the description.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specifies the name of the affinity group that this cmdlet modifies.
Specifies a label for the affinity group. The label can be up to 100 characters long.
Specifies the description of the affinity group. The description can be up to 1024 characters long.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.
Specifies the name of the affinity group that this cmdlet modifies.
Specifies a label for the affinity group. The label can be up to 100 characters long.
Specifies the description of the affinity group. The description can be up to 1024 characters long.
Specifies the Azure profile from which this cmdlet reads. If you do not specify a profile, this cmdlet reads from the local default profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1: Modify an affinity group --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Set-AzureAffinityGroup -Name "South01" -Label "SouthUSProduction" -Description "Production applications for Southern US locations"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command modifies the label of the affinity group named South01 to be SouthUSProduction The command also modifies the description.
